C. diazotrophica was first isolated from the roots of a mangrove plant, Avicennia marina, in Vietnam. It is capable of growing under both aerobic and microaerobic conditions, and it can utilize a variety of organic compounds as carbon and energy sources.

The genome of C. diazotrophica has been sequenced, revealing the presence of genes involved in nitrogen fixation, as well as genes responsible for the production of plant growth-promoting substances, such as indole-3-acetic acid (IAA). These characteristics suggest that C. diazotrophica may have potential applications in agriculture as a biofertilizer or plant growth-promoting agent.

Overall, Celerinatantimonas diazotrophica is a unique, nitrogen-fixing bacterium with potential ecological and agricultural significance due to its ability to enhance plant growth and development.
